column8: This is strange, because /u/ is already a high vowel and cannot be raised further. Also, the vowel /ʌ/ is lower than /u/.
These are *spelling* differences, not necessarily pronunciation differences, since these n's would be pronounced as m's anyway.

Single quotation marks are used exclusively for linguistic meanings, e.g. Latin *habere* ‘have’ is not cognate with Old English *hafian* ‘have’. Quotes within quotes are not treated in a special way.

The syntax suggests that *who* is the subject of the verb *concerted* and that *measures* is the object. As I read it, however, *concerted* is an adjective, so the main verb of this clause is missing.

NB many of my comments are suggestions for additional punctuation, which will help to break up the longer sentences and improve readability. Generally, I've suggested adding a comma where it took me a couple of goes to parse a sentence.

column7: I suggest a sentence break here
column8: i.e., '...and Ireland. It was not until...'
There's no need to give the details here.
e.g.: 'one ship's captain, stressing the large nature of the ship and its sizable population, complained that...'

NB many of my comments concern Oxford commas, which sometimes you use and sometimes you don't. I think LSP don't mind whether or not you use the Oxford comma, as long as you're consistent. I've decided to flag the places where you don't use an Oxford comma, so you can add one, rather than the places where you do use one: the Oxford comma is standard in the publishing house and journal style sheets I'm familiar with; and because omission of an Oxford comma sometimes leads to incorrect parsing.

the first and third coordinates are PPs, but the middle coordinate is an NP. Add *in* to the second.

> '...similar to how taking an oath might, or signing a document, if the contract were written.'  (Presumably 'if the contract were written' should only have scope over 'signing a document', while 'might' should have scope over both 'taking an oath' and 'signing a document' – so it reads strangely to have 'might' inside 'if the contract were written'.)

This and subsequent suggestions of changing commas to semi-colons are a matter of taste; I personally prefer using semi-colons where there are more than two items in a listing, as it makes the boundaries between the different items more clear. Whatever you go for, consistency is key.
